captions.text:
Where Warhammer 40,000 is concerned, I&#39;m like 
a manically depressed kangaroo: up and down

and probably not the best person to be left in 
charge of moving the little figurines. At first,

I thought it was cringeworthy macho edgy 
teenager bullshit where they just took a

bunch of Tolkienesque fantasy races and 
stuck bionics into them until they looked

like electric whisks jammed with playdough, but 
it gained a certain amount of charm when I came to

the understanding that there&#39;s also some irony at 
work. I did some research on the Warhammer Wiki,

and when it goes on about Orks talking in absurd, 
phonetic Cockney accents and being genetically

closer to a fungus than a humanoid race, and 
there&#39;s a million billion squillion of them,

and they bite each other&#39;s faces off as a 
greeting, one gets the impression that the

author writes with eyerolling self-awareness, 
like a parent assuring their child that yes,

their drawing of a nine-legged horse 
is worthy of display in the Galleria

Uffizi. But I also wonder if everyone who 
appreciates Warhammer 40,000—and indeed,

a lot of Warhammer 40,000 itself—is entirely on 
board with the irony thing. Take Space Marines.

I have one main question. Am I supposed to 
think Space Marines are laughable or badass?

On the one hand, they&#39;re a bunch of fanatically 
religious, emotionally stunted weirdoes

proportioned like the Sugar Puff Monster all 
trussed up in their overly detailed big boy

trousers and generally look like they stepped 
straight out of a drawing that a troubled teenage

wargamer would scribble on the back of a school 
folder, but then, we have games like Space Marine

2, where the main characters set their mouths into 
thin lines of determination, pull up their big boy

trousers, and grimly murder a million billion 
insectoid reptile thingies against a variety of

epic backgrounds. The main character, Titus, 
could go either way on the badass-ridiculous

spectrum. On the one hand, he seems to be 
presented with an entirely straight face,

all honor and duty and duty and trousers, but 
then he takes his helmet off in the prologue,

and I immediately snort laughed at his dad 
haircut that makes him look like a roided-up

Kevin Spacey. And then he spends the whole story 
campaign just radiating angry dad energy, playing

off one of his sidekicks, who I think is supposed 
to be the Space Marine equivalent of a brash,

young, pretty boy because his face only somewhat 
resembles a partially assembled jigsaw puzzle.

Anyway. Space Marine 2 is a third-person 
shooter and, spoiler warning, the sequel

to Space Marine 1. In Space Marine 1, you were 
mainly fighting Orks, and in Space Marine 2,

you&#39;ve moved on to Tyranids, sort of the result 
of Giger&#39;s Alien spending too much time in the

gentleman&#39;s toilets outside Left 4 Dead&#39;s house. 
And thank goodness, if Titus had had to spend any

more time fighting Orks, there might have been 
a dangerous amount of personality in the game.

The main selling point for Space Marine 2 in 
this age of endemic Soulslikes, open worlds,

and live service gear grinding bullshit, is 
that, big boy trousers aside, it&#39;s refreshingly

straightforward. Enemies come at you, and you 
shoot them. With one of about 19 different rifles

that I had tremendous difficulty telling apart. 
I&#39;d load myself out with a bolt rifle and then

run into a weapon crate mid-mission, going, 
&quot;Would you like to switch to a bolt carbine,

a heavy bolt carbine, or a heavy instigator 
bolt carbine rifle?&quot; I don&#39;t fucking know.

This is like going out to dinner with wine snobs. 
What do I think of the red? It doesn&#39;t taste like

cyanide, and it&#39;s making me feel inordinately 
confident, so I&#39;d say it&#39;s doing its job.

And Space Marine 2 is doing its job as well if 
its job is to be visually spectacular. I fondly

remember a couple of occasions where I&#39;d be in 
ruined, ridiculously huge industrial facility

number 5,012, and in the distance, I&#39;d see hordes 
of Tyranids stampeding across the hills of the

skybox and think, &quot;Gosh, that&#39;s impressive. Wait, 
why do those Tyranids look like they&#39;re running

straight towards me? Oh shit, that&#39;s not a 
skybox! That&#39;s not a skybox at all! And now

they&#39;re climbing up each other to get to me like 
the zombies in that one film no one remembers,

and now my big boy trousers are brimming 
with insecure macho urine.&quot; I&#39;ve heard many

correspondents laud Space Marine 2 for evoking 
the spirit of the Xbox 360 era of shooters,

but while it is a linear series of arena fights 
with more shades of brown than an infrequently

changed incontinence pad, and our main character 
does look like the midpoint between a fully

armored medieval knight and the Michelin Man, the 
combat system is as much melee as gun-focused,

complete with the now-inevitable timed parry, fat 
lot of good though it is when you&#39;re being swarmed

by 300 Tyranids taking it in turns to treat your 
armor like a great big screaming advent calendar.

The other thing that makes it reminiscent 
of the 360 era is the surprisingly brief

main campaign. Or is it? There&#39;s actually a 
separate co-op story mode where you play as

an ancillary team of equally big-boy-trousered 
fellas doing side objectives in parallel to what

Titus is doing in the main story, but it&#39;s only 
a co-op mode in the sense that you&#39;re not allowed

to park in the bike lane. Maybe, but I&#39;m going 
to anyway. And if you just play the co-op mode

by yourself with two bots, then it&#39;s essentially 
another single-player campaign. A more grindy and

repetitive one. But you know what? Considering 
that I said Black Myth: Wukong would&#39;ve been

better if it&#39;d just been boss fights back to back 
and that most triple A story campaigns these days

would seriously benefit from editing themselves 
down to a conservative hundred billion hours,

I&#39;m on board with cutting down the main campaign 
to the important bits and leaving all the grindy

in-between gameplay off to the side where it 
doesn&#39;t have to bother me. It&#39;s like cutting

the fatty bits off my steak. I appreciate 
that because I don&#39;t like the fatty bits,

but I know some people do, so I&#39;ll leave 
them on the plate for such vile maggotty

perverts to do whatever it is they 
need for their sick gratification.

Having said that, perhaps a little too much was 
thrown to the perverts. I mentioned that I enjoyed

the relentless spectacle of fighting Tyranids, but 
that whole aspect of the story abruptly ends about

halfway through the game when all the Tyranids 
just drop dead mid-mission and someone goes,

&quot;Hooray, one of the teams in the co-op campaign 
just killed the Tyranid queen or whatever.&quot; And

you know, a significant boss fight resolving what 
has been the major threat for the entire story up

to this point is not what I would call a fatty 
bit of steak to be cut off for someone else. I

wanted that. This is more a girlfriend taking one 
too many fries situation. Further embittering the

pill, we then spend the rest of the game mostly 
fighting fucking Chaos Space Marines. Yeah,

I probably would complain if it&#39;d just been 
Tyranids from start to finish with no enemy

variety, but now EVERYONE on the battlefield 
is dressed like a children&#39;s play structure

in Chernobyl, and I keep accidentally 
shooting the wrong dudes. In summary,

there&#39;s a lot one can appreciate in Space 
Marine 2&#39;s simplicity. In gameplay, I mean,

the plot hinges a little too much on prior 
knowledge of the last game and Warhammer

40,000 lore in general. On two occasions near 
the end, someone dramatically walks in or takes

their helmet off, and I had to awkwardly bluff 
my way through recognizing them. &quot;Oh, wow! What

a reveal! Another big, chonky dude who looks like 
Julius Caesar being played by a concrete mixer.&quot;
